title: James Erskine, 6th Earl of Buchan
text: James Erskine, 6th Earl of Buchan( died 1640), was the eldest son of John Erskine, Earl of Mar, by his second wife, Marie Stewart, daughter of Esme Stewart, Duke of Lennox.

title: James Erskine, 6th Earl of Buchan
text: He married Mary Douglas, 6th Countess of Buchan, daughter and heiress of James Douglas, 5th Earl of Buchan, and assumed the title of Earl of Buchan.

title: James Erskine, 6th Earl of Buchan
text: This title was confirmed by a royal charter, dated 22 March 1617, the countess resigning her rights in his favour, and he was allowed the possession and exercise of all honours, dignities, and precedence of former earls of Buchan.

title: James Erskine, 6th Earl of Buchan
text: A decree of the court of sessions, 25 July 1628, restored to Buchan and his wife the precedency over the earls of Eglinton, Montrose, Cassilis, Caithness, and Glencairn, which had been claimed by them, and granted by a former decree in 1606.

title: James Erskine, 6th Earl of Buchan
text: On the accession of Charles I, Buchan became one of the lords of the bedchamber.

title: James Erskine, 6th Earl of Buchan
text: He lived chiefly in London, where he died in 1640.

title: James Erskine, 6th Earl of Buchan
text: He was buried at Auchterhouse, Forfarshire.

title: James Erskine, 6th Earl of Buchan
text: His wife died before him in 1628.

title: James Erskine, 6th Earl of Buchan
text: They left six children, two sons, James, who succeeded to the title, and John, and four daughters.

title: Alexander Stewart, Earl of Buchan
text: Alexander Stewart, Earl of Buchan, Alasdair Mór mac an Rígh, and called the Wolf of Badenoch (1343 – 20 June 1405), was the third surviving son of King Robert II of Scotland and youngest by his first wife, Elizabeth Mure of Rowallan.

title: Alexander Stewart, Earl of Buchan
text: He was the first Earl of Buchan since John Comyn, from 1382 until his death.

title: Alexander Stewart, Earl of Buchan
text: Alexander married the widowed Euphemia I, Countess of Ross, but they had no children.

title: Alexander Stewart, Earl of Buchan
text: He did have a large family by his longtime mistress, Mairead inghean Eachainn.

title: Alexander Stewart, Earl of Buchan
text: Alexander was Justiciar of Scotia for a time, but not an effective one.

title: Alexander Stewart, Earl of Buchan
text: He held large territories in the north of Scotland before eventually losing a large part of them.

title: Alexander Stewart, Earl of Buchan
text: Alexander is remembered for his destruction of the royal burgh of Elgin and its cathedral.

title: Alexander Stewart, Earl of Buchan
text: His nickname was earned due to his notorious cruelty and rapacity, but there is no proof that it was used during his lifetime.

title: Jardine Comyn
text: Jardine Comyn, Lord of Inverallochy, also known as Jordan, was a son of William Comyn, Lord of Badenoch later the Earl of Buchan and was granted the lands of Inverallochy from his father upon William becoming the Earl of Buchan, jure uxoris of his second wife Margaret, Countess of Buchan.

title: Alice Comyn, Countess of Buchan
text: Alice Comyn, Countess of Buchan, Lady Beaumont( 1289 – 3 July 1349) was a Scottish noblewoman, a member of the powerful Comyn family which supported the Balliols, claimants to the disputed Scottish throne against their rivals, the Bruces.

title: Alice Comyn, Countess of Buchan
text: She was the niece of John Comyn, Earl of Buchan, to whom she was also heiress, and after his death the Earldom of Buchan was successfully claimed by her husband Henry de Beaumont, Earl of Buchan, by right of his wife.

title: Alice Comyn, Countess of Buchan
text: His long struggle to claim her Earldom of Buchan was one of the causes of the Second War of Scottish Independence. Alice was the maternal grandmother of Blanche of Lancaster, and thus great- grandmother of King Henry IV of England.

title: Robert II of Scotland
text: Robert II (2 March 1316 – 19 April 1390) reigned as King of Scots from 1371 to his death as the first monarch of the House of Stewart.

title: Robert II of Scotland
text: He was the son of Walter Stewart, 6th High Steward of Scotland and of Marjorie Bruce, daughter of the Scottish king Robert the Bruce by his first wife Isabella of Mar.

title: Robert II of Scotland
text: Edward Bruce, younger brother of Robert the Bruce, was named heir presumptive but died without heirs on 3 December 1318.

title: Robert II of Scotland
text: Marjorie had died probably in 1317 in a riding accident and parliament decreed her infant son, Robert Stewart, as heir presumptive, but this lapsed on 5 March 1324 on the birth of a son, David, to King Robert and his second wife, Elizabeth de Burgh.

title: Robert II of Scotland
text: Robert Stewart became High Steward of Scotland on his father's death on 9 April 1326, and in the same year parliament confirmed the young Steward as heir should Prince David die without a successor.

title: Robert II of Scotland
text: In 1329 King Robert I died and the six-year-old David succeeded to the throne under the guardianship of Thomas Randolph, Earl of Moray.

title: Robert II of Scotland
text: Edward Balliol, son of King John Balliol—assisted by the English and those Scottish nobles who had been disinherited by Robert I—invaded Scotland inflicting heavy defeats on the Bruce party on 11 August 1332 at Dupplin Moor and Halidon Hill on 19 July 1333.

title: Robert II of Scotland
text: Robert, who had fought at Halidon joined his uncle, King David in refuge in Dumbarton Castle.

title: Robert II of Scotland
text: David escaped to France in 1334 and parliament, still functioning, appointed Robert and John Randolph, 3rd Earl of Moray as joint Guardians of the kingdom.

title: Robert II of Scotland
text: Randolph was captured by the English in July 1335 and in the same year Robert submitted to Balliol bringing about the removal of his guardianship.

title: Robert II of Scotland
text: The office was reinstated in 1338 and Robert held it until David's return from France in June 1341.

title: Robert II of Scotland
text: Hostilities continued and Robert was with David at the Neville's Cross on 17 October 1346 and either escaped or fled the field but David was captured and remained a prisoner until he was ransomed in October 1357.

title: Robert II of Scotland
text: Robert married Elizabeth Mure around 1348, legitimising his four sons and five daughters.

title: Robert II of Scotland
text: His subsequent marriage to Euphemia de Ross in 1355 produced two sons and two surviving daughters.

title: Robert II of Scotland
text: Robert rebelled against the King in 1363 but submitted to him following a threat to his right of succession.

title: Robert II of Scotland
text: David died in 1371 and Robert succeeded him at the age of fifty-five.

title: Robert II of Scotland
text: The border magnates continued to attack English-held zones in southern Scotland and by 1384, the Scots had re-taken most of the occupied lands.

title: Robert II of Scotland
text: Robert ensured that Scotland was included in the Anglo-French truce of 1384 and that was a factor in the coup in November when he lost control of the country first to his eldest son, John, and then from 1388 to John's younger brother, Robert.

title: Robert II of Scotland
text: King Robert died in Dundonald Castle in 1390 and was buried at Scone Abbey.

title: Mairead inghean Eachainn
text: Mairead inghean Eachainn, also known as Mairead nic Eachainn, was a consort of Alexander Stewart, Earl of Buchan( a man also known as the" Wolf of Badenoch").

title: Mairead inghean Eachainn
text: She was the daughter of a man named Eachann, and probably the mother of several children, including Alexander's like- named son, Alexander Stewart, Earl of Mar.

title: John de Innes
text: John de Innes( c.

title: John de Innes
text: 1370 – 1414) was medieval Scottish churchman.

title: John de Innes
text: Born probably in Moray, he went to France in his youth, receiving a bachelorate in civil law from the University of Paris by 1396 and in canon law by 1407.

title: John de Innes
text: His education was partly paid for by the prebend of Duffus and a grant from Alexander Bur, Bishop of Moray, taken by Bur from the judicial profits of his diocese.

title: John de Innes
text: During Innes' study period, he was also pursuing an ecclesiastical career, being Archdeacon of Caithness from 1396 until 1398, and Dean of Ross, from some point between 1396 and 1398 until 1407.

title: John de Innes
text: He gave up the latter position in that year, having been elected as Bishop of Moray sometime in late 1406, and receiving consecration from Pope Benedict XIII in either Italy or southern France in the following January.

title: John de Innes
text: Innes was bishop for over seven years, and died at Elgin on 2 August 1414.

title: John de Innes
text: Innes has been traditionally credited with supervising much of the rebuilding to Elgin Cathedral.

title: John de Innes
text: The historian David Ditchburn believes Innes was an ally, and possibly even a client, of Alexander Stewart, Earl of Mar, and perhaps his father Alexander Stewart, Earl of Buchan, the latter of whom was the warlord responsible for burning down Elgin Cathedral during the episcopate of Alexander Bur.

title: Alexander Comyn, Earl of Buchan
text: Alexander Comyn, 2nd Earl of Buchan( died 1289) was a Scoto- Norman magnate who was one of the most important figures in the 13th century Kingdom of Scotland.

title: Alexander Comyn, Earl of Buchan
text: He was the son of William Comyn, jure uxoris Earl of Buchan, and Marjory, Countess of Buchan, the heiress of the last native Scottish Mormaer of Buchan, Fergus.

title: Alexander Comyn, Earl of Buchan
text: He was the chief counsellor of Alexander III, King of Scots for the entire period of the king's majority and, as Scotland's leading magnate, played a key role in safeguarding the independence of the Scottish monarchy.

title: Alexander Comyn, Earl of Buchan
text: During his long career, Alexander Comyn was Justiciar of Scotia( 1258 – 89), Constable of Scotland( 1275 – 89), Sheriff of Wigtown( 1263 – 66), Sheriff of Dingwall( 1264 – 66), Ballie of Inverie( in Knoydart) and finally, Guardian of Scotland( 1286 – 89) during the first interregnum following the death of Alexander III.

title: Alexander Comyn, Earl of Buchan
text: In 1284 he joined with other Scottish noblemen who acknowledged Margaret of Norway as the heiress to King Alexander.

title: Alexander Comyn, Earl of Buchan
text: He died sometime after 10 July 1289.

title: Alexander Comyn, Earl of Buchan
text: Alexander had at least nine children with his wife, Elizabeth, daughter of Roger de Quincy, 2nd Earl of Winchester:

title: Mahesh Bhatt
text: Mahesh Bhatt( born 20 September 1948) is an Indian film director, producer and screenwriter known for his works exclusively in Hindi cinema.

title: Mahesh Bhatt
text: A stand- out film from his earlier period is" Saaransh"( 1984), screened at the 14th Moscow International Film Festival.

title: Mahesh Bhatt
text: It became India's official entry for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film for that year.

title: Mahesh Bhatt
text: The 1986 film" Naam" was his first piece of commercial cinema.

title: Mahesh Bhatt
text: In 1987, he turned producer with the film" Kabzaa" under the banner," Vishesh Films", with his brother Mukesh Bhatt.

title: Mahesh Bhatt
text: Bhatt went on to become one of the most recognized directors of the Indian film industry in the next decade, giving both art- house works such as" Daddy"( 1989) and" Swayam"( 1991), as well as commercial romantic hits like" Awaargi"( 1990)," Aashiqui"( 1990) and" Dil Hai Ki Manta Nahin"( 1991), in which he cast Pooja with actor Aamir Khan.

title: Mahesh Bhatt
text: He next directed" Sadak"( 1991) which remains his highest grossing either directed or produced under the banner," Vishesh Films".

title: Mahesh Bhatt
text: During the 1990s Bhatt won critical acclaim for" Sir"( 1993), along with other hits such as" Gumraah"( 1993) and" Criminal"( 1994).

title: Mahesh Bhatt
text: In 1994 he won the National Film Award – Special Jury Award for directing" Hum Hain Rahi Pyar Ke"( 1993).

title: Mahesh Bhatt
text: In 1999, he directed the autobiographical Zakhm, which has garnered the Nargis Dutt Award for Best Feature Film on National Integration.

title: Mahesh Bhatt
text: Bhatt has produced contemporary films such as" JismMurder" and" Woh Lamhe".

title: Mahesh Bhatt
text: He co-owns film producing company Vishesh Films with his brother Mukesh Bhatt.

title: Riccardo Schicchi
text: Riccardo Schicchi (Augusta, Sicily, 14 March 1953 - Rome, 9 December 2012) was an Italian pornographer.

title: Riccardo Schicchi
text: Graduated from art school with a specialization in photography, Schicchi began by being a photographer for "Epoca", travelling around in several places of the world, including war zones.

title: Riccardo Schicchi
text: After meeting Ilona Staller, both acted as hosts of the radio show "Voulez-vous coucher avec moi?

title: Riccardo Schicchi
text: " featuring discussions about sex, with live calls from the audience.

title: Riccardo Schicchi
text: Staller was renamed "Cicciolina".

title: Riccardo Schicchi
text: In 1983 the duo founded the model agency "Diva Futura".

title: Riccardo Schicchi
text: Moana Pozzi was another source of popularity for Schicchi; Pozzi was the face of Schicchi's Partito dell'Amore (Love Party), a parody of Italian political parties: in 1990, the Love Party was unable to cross over the minimum limit for admission into the lowest Chamber, yet it still amassed a significant number of preferences for Pozzi.

title: Riccardo Schicchi
text: Eva Henger was also discovered by Schicchi and later became his wife in 1994.

title: Riccardo Schicchi
text: The couple had two children, Mercedesz (1991) and Riccardo Jr. (1995), before parting. Henger currently has another relationship, yet the couple never officially divorced.

title: Riccardo Schicchi
text: Schicchi was ailed with Diabetes mellitus type 2, that led to his hospitalization in 2012 for diabetic coma, assisted by Henger.

title: Riccardo Schicchi
text: The disease also impaired his vision and caused chronic kidney disease.

title: Riccardo Schicchi
text: ; Schicchi died in San Pietro Hospital, Rome.

text: According to one obituary, he was "a prime exponent of that style, being a master of swift exposition and fast action.

text: His no-nonsense approach also made him a fine serial director, and when given the chance of a top-budget adventure film he gave his studio one of its biggest hits in Arabian Nights.

text: " Another said he "was a prime example of a no-frills director of Bs, who got his job done quickly, competently and cheaply.

title: Ladies Courageous

title: Amazon basin

title: Secret Path
text: Secret Path is a Canadian multimedia art project including a music album and tour, a graphic novel, and a television film.

title: Secret Path
text: The centrepiece is" Secret Path", the fifth studio album by Gord Downie and the final album released during his lifetime.

title: Secret Path
text: Released on October 18, 2016, the project is a concept album about Chanie Wenjack, a young Anishinaabe boy from the Marten Falls First Nation who died in 1966 while trying to return home after escaping from an Indian residential school.

title: Secret Path
text: All proceeds from the album and book are being donated to the University of Manitoba's National Centre for Truth and Reconciliation project.

title: Secret Path
text: The album was accompanied by a graphic novel of the same name, written by Downie and illustrated by Jeff Lemire, as well as an animated television film aired on CBC Television on October 23, 2016.

title: Secret Path
text: Downie performed the album in a concert at Roy Thomson Hall on October 21, 2016, which was his last- ever full concert performance in his lifetime and was attended by members of the Wenjack family.

title: Secret Path
text: The concert was aired by CBC Television in October 2017 following Downie's death.

Thus he was provided to Ely 'in commendam' on 27 September 1437.

title: Jia Yinghua

title: Jia Yinghua
text: The Japanese version of The Later Half of the Last Emperor's Life is a bestseller in Japan, attracting great attention and garnering enormous popularity.

title: Jia Yinghua
text: According to authoritative media and press organizations in more than 100 countries and regions, including China, the United Kingdom, the United States, France, Japan, Hong Kong, Macao, and Taiwan this book is a successful continuation of" From Emperor to Citizen": The Autobiography of Aisin- Gioro Pu Yi written by Pu Yi himself.

title: Jia Yinghua
text: The Chinese version of" The Later Half of the Last Emperor ’s Life" is always a domestic bestseller and has been published nine times in total, and also won the Gold Key Award in the 5th Chinese Books Fair.

title: Jia Yinghua
text: His calligraphic works were also incorporated into" First Exhibition of Chinese Celebrities ’ Calligraphic Works Exhibition of Contemporary Celebrities ’ Paintings and Calligraphies", etc. His book" The Extraordinary Life of The Last Emperor of China" was awarded the country's top prize for biographies in 2013.

title: Love & Mercy (film)
text: Love & Mercy (stylized as love&mercy) is a 2014 American biographical drama film directed by Bill Pohlad that focuses on the Beach Boys' co-founder and leader Brian Wilson and his struggles with mental illness during the 1960s and 1980s.

title: Love & Mercy (film)
text: The film derives its title from Wilson's 1988 song of the same name, and stars Paul Dano and John Cusack as the young and middle-aged Wilson, respectively, with Elizabeth Banks as his second wife Melinda Ledbetter, and Paul Giamatti as his psychotherapist Dr. Eugene Landy.

title: Love & Mercy (film)
text: The film alternates between Wilson's production of the album "Pet Sounds" (1966) and his treatment under Landy's 24-hour therapy program in the late 1980s.

title: Love & Mercy (film)
text: Wilson called the film "very factual. " He had little involvement with its making, whereas Ledbetter was relied upon for the 1980s portions.

title: Love & Mercy (film)
text: The cast and crew maintained that nothing in the film was a "Hollywood" embellishment and that everything was intended to be as factual as possible.

title: Love & Mercy (film)
text: Conversely, Landy's son Evan felt that his father was unfairly portrayed.

title: Love & Mercy (film)
text: Some minor historical inaccuracies were noted by critics, a number of which relate to the minimal coverage devoted to Wilson's family and collaborators.

title: Love & Mercy (film)
text: Ledbetter said that Landy's treatment of Wilson "was even worse" than the film portrays.

title: Love & Mercy (film)
text: "Love and Mercy" premiered at the 2014 Toronto International Film Festival on September 7, 2014 and was released by Lionsgate and Roadside Attractions on June 5, 2015.

title: Love & Mercy (film)
text: It grossed $28.6 million over a $10 million budget and received critical acclaim from reviewers; later, it was nominated for two Golden Globes: Best Supporting Actor – Motion Picture (Paul Dano) and Best Original Song ("One Kind of Love").

title: Love & Mercy (film)
text: A soundtrack album that includes the original score by Atticus Ross was released on August 14, 2015.

title: Charlotte Montagu Douglas Scott, Duchess of Buccleuch
text: Charlotte Anne Montagu Douglas Scott, Duchess of Buccleuch and Queensberry, VA(" née" Thynne; 10 April 1811 – 18 March 1895) was a British peeress.

title: Charlotte Montagu Douglas Scott, Duchess of Buccleuch
text: A daughter of Thomas Thynne, 2nd Marquess of Bath, Charlotte married Walter Montagu Douglas Scott, 5th Duke of Buccleuch in 1829.

title: Charlotte Montagu Douglas Scott, Duchess of Buccleuch
text: They had seven children, including William Montagu Douglas Scott, 6th Duke of Buccleuch; Henry Douglas- Scott- Montagu, 1st Baron Montagu of Beaulieu; and the Royal Navy admiral Lord Charles Montagu Douglas Scott.

title: Charlotte Montagu Douglas Scott, Duchess of Buccleuch
text: From 1841 to 1846, the Duchess of Buccleuch served as the Mistress of the Robes to Queen Victoria as a member of Robert Peel's ministry.

title: Charlotte Montagu Douglas Scott, Duchess of Buccleuch
text: Her husband, a staunch Conservative, also served in Peel's ministry, and the Duchess used the connection to gain patronage for her brothers.

title: Charlotte Montagu Douglas Scott, Duchess of Buccleuch
text: She and the Queen remained lifelong friends, with the latter serving as godmother to Charlotte's daughter Lady Victoria.

title: Charlotte Montagu Douglas Scott, Duchess of Buccleuch
text: The Duchess advised her on Scotland, and later converted to Roman Catholicism in 1860.

title: Charlotte Montagu Douglas Scott, Duchess of Buccleuch
text: She engaged in philanthropic efforts in Scotland, and died in 1895 at Ditton Park.

title: John Montagu Douglas Scott, 7th Duke of Buccleuch

title: Marian Montagu Douglas Scott
text: Elmhirst was also a first cousin of Lady Alice Montagu Douglas Scott, who became the Duchess of Gloucester after her wedding to Prince Henry, and an aunt- by- marriage of Queen Elizabeth II.

title: Ellnora Krannert
text: Ellnora Decker Krannert (May 20, 1890 - July 6, 1974) was a philanthropist with a passion for the arts, drama, dance, and music.

title: Ellnora Krannert
text: Ellnora was born in Noblesville, Indiana to Pheobe Katherine Spencer Decker and Philip Greene.

title: Ellnora Krannert
text: She earned a bachelor's degree in music from Brenau College and was bestowed honorary doctorates in the humanities, law, fine arts, and music from University of Indianapolis, University of Evansville, Indiana University, and Butler University, respectively.

title: Ellnora Krannert
text: In 1919, she married Herman C. Krannert in Anderson, Indiana.

title: Ellnora Krannert
text: They moved to Indianapolis in 1925 and founded the Inland Container Corporation.

title: Ellnora Krannert
text: Ellnora and Herman made several transformative gifts to the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, where Herman had earned a mechanical engineering degree.

title: Ellnora Krannert
text: Because of Ellnora's passion for the arts, the couple chose to support projects dedicated to those fields.

title: Ellnora Krannert
text: She was committed to making the Midwest a center of culture and the arts as well as agriculture and industry.

title: Ellnora Krannert
text: She and her husband gave funds to establish Krannert Art Museum, which opened in 1961, and Krannert Center for the Performing Arts, which opened in 1969.

title: Ellnora Krannert
text: Ellnora contributed to the design of the Krannert Center and helped selecting colors, materials, and landscaping designs.

title: Ellnora Krannert
text: Unhappy with having to wait on the street during the intermissions of Broadway performances, she urged architect Max Abramovitz to incorporate a large indoor space where crowd could gather, an aspect of the design that has been characterized as transformative in that the space functionally resembles a piazza or public square rather than a traditional lobby.

title: Ellnora Krannert
text: Ellnora Guitar Festival, named in her honor, is held biennially at Krannert Center.

title: Ellnora Krannert
text: Ellnora and Herman also made substantial gifts to hospitals, universities, and museums in Indiana.

title: Ellnora Krannert
text: They established the Robert M. Moore Heart Clinic at Wishard Memorial Hospital in 1952.

title: Ellnora Krannert
text: This became the Krannert Institute of Cardiology, which is now part of the Indiana University School of Medicine.

title: Ellnora Krannert
text: They also founded the Krannert Foundation and Krannert Charitable Trust.

title: Ellnora Krannert
text: They established the Krannert School of Management and the Krannert Graduate School of Industrial Administration at Purdue University.

title: Ellnora Krannert
text: At the Indianapolis Museum of Art, Krannert Pavilion was named in their honor.

title: Herman C. Krannert

text: Krannert was married to Ellnora Decker Krannert.

title: Rumbold of Mechelen

title: Rumbold of Mechelen
text: Saint Rumbold's feast day is celebrated by the Roman Catholic Church, and Western Rite Orthodox Churches, on 24 June; and it is celebrated in Ireland on 3 July.

title: Rumbold of Mechelen

title: Rumbold of Mechelen

title: Rumbold of Mechelen
text: Twenty- five paintings in the choir illustrate his life.

title: Miles Davis
text: Miles Dewey Davis III (May 26, 1926September 28, 1991) was an American jazz trumpeter, bandleader, and composer.

title: Miles Davis
text: He is among the most influential and acclaimed figures in the history of jazz and 20th century music.

title: Miles Davis
text: Davis adopted a variety of musical directions in a five-decade career that kept him at the forefront of many major stylistic developments in jazz.

title: Miles Davis
text: Born and raised in Illinois, Davis left to study at the Juilliard School in New York City, before dropping out and making his professional debut as a member of saxophonist Charlie Parker's bebop quintet from 1944 to 1948.

title: Miles Davis
text: Shortly after, he recorded the "Birth of the Cool" sessions for Capitol Records, which were instrumental to the development of cool jazz.

title: Miles Davis
text: In the early 1950s, Miles Davis recorded some of the earliest hard bop music while on Prestige Records but did so haphazardly due to a heroin addiction.

title: Miles Davis
text: After a widely acclaimed comeback performance at the Newport Jazz Festival in 1955, he signed a long-term contract with Columbia Records and recorded the 1957 album "'Round About Midnight".

title: Miles Davis
text: It was his first work with saxophonist John Coltrane and bassist Paul Chambers, key members of the sextet he led into the early 1960s.

title: Miles Davis
text: During this period, he alternated between orchestral jazz collaborations with arranger Gil Evans, such as the Spanish-influenced "Sketches of Spain" (1960), and band recordings, such as "Milestones" (1958) and "Kind of Blue" (1959).

title: Miles Davis
text: The latter recording remains one of the most popular jazz albums of all time, having sold over four million copies in the U.S. Davis made several line-up changes while recording "Someday My Prince Will Come" (1961), his 1961 Blackhawk concerts, and "Seven Steps to Heaven" (1963), another mainstream success that introduced bassist Ron Carter, pianist Herbie Hancock, and drummer Tony Williams.

title: Miles Davis
text: After adding saxophonist Wayne Shorter to his new quintet in 1964, Davis led them on a series of more abstract recordings often composed by the band members, helping pioneer the post-bop genre with albums such as "E.S.P" (1965) and "Miles Smiles" (1967), before transitioning into his electric period.

title: Miles Davis
text: During the 1970s, he experimented with rock, funk, African rhythms, emerging electronic music technology, and an ever-changing line-up of musicians, including keyboardist Joe Zawinul, drummer Al Foster, and guitarist John McLaughlin.

title: Miles Davis
text: This period, beginning with Davis' 1969 studio album " In a Silent Way" and concluding with the 1975 concert recording "Agharta", was the most controversial in his career, alienating and challenging many in jazz.

title: Miles Davis
text: His million-selling 1970 record "Bitches Brew" helped spark a resurgence in the genre's commercial popularity with jazz fusion as the decade progressed.

title: Miles Davis
text: After a five-year retirement due to poor health, Davis resumed his career in the 1980s, employing younger musicians and pop sounds on albums such as "The Man with the Horn" (1981) and "Tutu" (1986).

title: Miles Davis
text: Critics were generally unreceptive but the decade garnered the trumpeter his highest level of commercial recognition.

title: Miles Davis
text: He performed sold-out concerts worldwide while branching out into visual arts, film, and television work, before his death in 1991 from the combined effects of a stroke, pneumonia and respiratory failure.

title: Yang Yanzhao
text: Yang Yanzhao (楊延昭) (958 – 9 February 1014), named Yang Yanlang (楊延朗) before 1012 and Liu Yanlang (劉延朗) before 979, was a military general in ancient China's Northern Song Dynasty.

title: Yang Yanzhao
text: For over 2 decades he defended Song's northern border against the Khitan-ruled Liao Dynasty, helping Song thwart Liao's repeated invasion attempts between 999 and 1004.

title: Yang Yanzhao
text: He was one of Yang Ye's 7 sons.

title: Yang Yanzhao
text: " History of Song" mentions that he was called Yang Liulang (楊六郎, literally "Yang's 6th son") by the Khitans who feared him.

title: Yang Yanzhao
text: In the largely fictional legends of "Generals of the Yang Family", Yang Yanzhao is Yang Ye's 6th eldest son to explain this nickname, even though historians believe he was actually the eldest or 2nd eldest son.

title: Cyril Frankel
text: Cyril S. Frankel( 28 December 1921 – 7 June 2017) was a British film and television director.

title: Cyril Frankel
text: His career in television began in 1953 and he directed for over 30 TV programmes until 1990.

title: Cyril Frankel
text: He was born in Stoke Newington, London.

title: Cyril Frankel
text: He directed many episodes of popular British TV shows, such as" The Avengers", and the pilot episodes of the ITC Entertainment shows" Randall and Hopkirk( Deceased)" and" Department S" in 1969.

title: Cyril Frankel
text: In 1970, he directed" Timelash", an episode of" UFO", which he described as a very interesting script and one of his personal favourites.

title: Cyril Frankel
text: Frankel also directed many documentaries and feature films, including" Never Take Sweets from a Stranger"( 1960) and" School for Scoundrels"( 1960; taking over from Robert Hamer, who was credited as sole director).

title: Cyril Frankel
text: One of his films," Man of Africa"( 1953)- the first film to feature a cast made up of relatively unknown black actors- was not released and was lost for some time.

title: Cyril Frankel
text: A complete copy has since been discovered and has been screened at a number of international film festivals.

title: Cyril Frankel
text: In terms of documentaries, Frankel supervised some of the films that were broadcast for the BBC arts series" Monitor"( 1958 – 65), among which was the first ballet programme to be filmed and edited to the choreography.

title: Cyril Frankel
text: Prior to his retirement, he became the ceramics expert for Bonhams auction house.

title: Cyril Frankel
text: A book," Modern Pots: Hans Coper, Lucie Rie and their Contemporaries- The Lisa Sainsbury Collection", was co-authored by Frankel and published in 2000.

title: Cyril Frankel
text: His memoir," Eye to Eye", was published by Bank House Books in 2009.

title: Cyril Frankel
text: Frankel died on 7 June 2017 at the age of 95.

title: Paul L. Stein
text: Paul Ludwig Stein( 4 February 1892 – 2 May 1951) was an Austrian- born film director with 67 films to his credit.

title: Paul L. Stein
text: Stein began his career in Berlin in 1918 and worked exclusively in the German silent film industry until 1926, when he first went to Hollywood, and spent the next five years commuting between Germany and the U.S., where he worked with stars such as Jeanette MacDonald, Lillian Gish and Constance Bennett.

title: Paul L. Stein
text: In 1931, Stein relocated to England after gaining a contract with British International Pictures, where he was assigned a number of big- name prestige productions, including some of the popular operetta films of the mid-1930s.

title: Paul L. Stein
text: These included" Blossom Time" and" Heart's Desire" starring his boyhood friend Richard Tauber, who also made cameo appearances in two of his post-war films" Waltz Time" and" Lisbon Story".

title: Paul L. Stein
text: For most his career, Stein's credits tended to be films primarily aimed at female audiences, although later he also directed crime and spy thrillers.

title: Paul L. Stein
text: Stein remained in England for the rest of his life and career, becoming a British citizen in 1938.

title: Po Saktiraydapatih
text: Po Saktiraydapatih (?

title: Po Saktiraydapatih
text: –1728), also spelled Po Saktiray Depatih, Po Saktiray Da Patih or Po Saktiraydaputih, was the king of Champa who ruled from 1695 to 1728.

title: Po Saktiraydapatih
text: In Vietnamese records, he was mentioned as Kế Bà Tử (繼婆子).

title: Po Saktiraydapatih
text: Po Saktiraydapatih was a younger brother of Po Saut.

title: Po Saktiraydapatih
text: In 1692, Po Saut revolted against Vietnamese Nguyễn lord and was captured.

title: Po Saktiraydapatih
text: Champa was annexed by Vietnam and became Vietnamese "Bình Thuận phủ" (平順府, present-day Bình Thuận and Ninh Thuận); Po Saktiraydapatih was appointed the governor of Bình Thuận with the title "khám lý" (勘理).

title: Po Saktiraydapatih
text: Chams were ordered to wear Vietnamese-style clothes and forced to adopt Vietnamese customs.

title: Po Saktiraydapatih
text: In 1693, a Cham aristocrat, Oknha Dat (Ốc nha Thát, 屋牙撻), revolted against Nguyễn lord.

title: Po Saktiraydapatih
text: He obtained the help of a Chinese immigrant, A Ban (阿班).

title: Po Saktiraydapatih
text: Though the rebellion was put down, Nguyễn Phúc Chu decided to restore Champa Kingdom because there was an outbreak of plague in Panduranga.

title: Po Saktiraydapatih
text: In 1694, Po Saktiraydapatih was crowned Champa king by Nguyễn lord with the title "Thuận Thành trấn vương" (順城鎮王, "king of Thuận Thành trấn"), though he had no authority over Vietnamese living in the area.

title: Po Saktiraydapatih
text: The king's palace was situated at Băl Canar, not far from Phan Rí.

title: Po Saktiraydapatih
text: The king had a company of Vietnamese soldiers, 30 men in total, for his personal protection.

title: Po Saktiraydapatih
text: In 1712, Po Saktiraydapatih obtained "five-point treatyNgũ điều Nghị định") with Vietnamese.

title: Po Saktiraydapatih
text: The treaty, at least in theory, remained in effect until the abolition of Cham "aboriginal kingship" in 1832.

title: Po Saktiraydapatih
text: Po Saktiraydapatih developed a close relationship with Nguyễn lord until his death in 1728.

title: Po Saktiraydapatih
text: After his death, an anti-Vietnamese rebellion occurred, but was swiftly defeated. However, members of his family were allowed to succeed him for several generations.

title: Ronald Mourad Cohen

title: Po Saut
text: Po Saut (?

title: Po Saut
text: –1693), also spelled Po Saot or Po Sot, was the king of Champa who ruled from 1660 to 1692.

title: Po Saut
text: In Vietnamese records, he was mentioned as Bà Tranh (婆爭).

title: Po Saut
text: He was also the last king of independent Champa.

title: Po Saut
text: Po Saut was a son of Po Rome.

title: Po Saut
text: He was of Churu and Rhade parentage.

title: Po Saut
text: He was a Muslim; in 1685, he requested a copy of the Quran from Father Ferret, a French missionary serving in Champa.

title: Po Saut
text: Champa came into conflict with Vietnam.

title: Po Saut
text: Po Saut revolted against Vietnamese Nguyễn lord in 1692.

title: Po Saut
text: Soon Champa was conquered by Vietnamese general Nguyễn Hữu Cảnh, Po Saut was captured and transferred to Phú Xuân (present-day Huế).

title: Po Saut
text: In there, Nguyễn Phúc Chu gave him a royal pardon.

title: Po Saut
text: He died in the next year.

title: Frederick II, Duke of Holstein-Gottorp
text: Frederick II, Duke of Holstein- Gottorp( 21 April 1568 – 15 June 1587) was a Danish- German nobleman.

title: Frederick II, Duke of Holstein-Gottorp
text: He was the eldest son of Duke Adolf of Holstein- Gottorp and his wife, Christine of Hesse( 1543- 1604).

title: Frederick II, Duke of Holstein-Gottorp
text: He inherited the ducal share of rule in the royal Danish- ducal condominium of the duchies of Holstein and of Schleswig when his father died in 1586, and died only a year later.

title: Philip, Duke of Holstein-Gottorp
text: Philip, Duke of Holstein- Gottorp( 10 August 1570 – 18 October 1590) was the second son of Adolf, Duke of Holstein- Gottorp( 1526 – 1586) and his wife, Christine of Hesse( 1543 – 1604).

title: Philip, Duke of Holstein-Gottorp
text: After the early death of his elder brother Frederick II in 1587, he inherited the ducal share of rule in the royal Danish- ducal condominium of the duchies of Holstein and of Schleswig at the age of 17.

title: Philip, Duke of Holstein-Gottorp
text: He died three years later.

title: Adolf, Duke of Holstein-Gottorp
text: Adolf of Denmark or Adolf of Holstein-Gottorp (25 January 1526 – 1 October 1586) was the first Duke of Holstein-Gottorp from the line of Holstein-Gottorp of the House of Oldenburg.

title: Adolf, Duke of Holstein-Gottorp
text: He was the third son of King Frederick I of Denmark and his second wife, Sophie of Pomerania.

title: Adolf, Duke of Holstein-Gottorp
text: King Frederick I had his son educated by Philip I, Landgrave of Hesse.

title: Adolf, Duke of Holstein-Gottorp
text: He spent four years at the Landgrave's castle in Kassel.

title: Adolf, Duke of Holstein-Gottorp
text: In 1544, Adolf, his brother Johann, and their half-brother King Christian III of Denmark, divided the duchies of Schleswig and Holstein.

title: Adolf, Duke of Holstein-Gottorp
text: The areas were divided according to approximately equal tax proceeds.

title: Adolf, Duke of Holstein-Gottorp
text: Adolf, as the youngest, was entitled the first choice.

title: Adolf, Duke of Holstein-Gottorp
text: Since he selected the part with the castle Gottorp, the line of the house Oldenburg created by him was called "Schleswig-Holstein-Gottorp".

title: Christian August of Holstein-Gottorp, Prince of Eutin
text: Christian August of Holstein-Gottorp-Eutin (11 January 1673 – 24 April 1726) was a cadet of the reigning ducal House of Holstein-Gottorp who became prince of Eutin, prince-bishop of Lübeck and regent of the Duchy of Holstein-Gottorp.

title: Christian August of Holstein-Gottorp, Prince of Eutin
text: He was the father of Adolf Frederick, King of Sweden, and the maternal grandfather of Catherine the Great, Empress of Russia.

title: Duchess Marie Elisabeth of Saxony

title: Christian Albert, Duke of Holstein-Gottorp

title: Christine of Hesse

title: Christine of Hesse
text: She exerted some political influence as a widow after 1586.

title: Stafford Northcote, 1st Earl of Iddesleigh
text: Stafford Henry Northcote, 1st Earl of Iddesleigh, (27 October 1818 – 12 January 1887), known as Sir Stafford Northcote from 1851 to 1885, was a British Conservative politician.

title: Stafford Northcote, 1st Earl of Iddesleigh
text: He served as Chancellor of the Exchequer between 1874 and 1880 and as Foreign Secretary between 1885 and 1886, and was one of only two people to hold the office of First Lord of the Treasury without ever being Prime Minister (the other being William Henry Smith, his successor-but-two, who, like Iddesleigh, also served in post in one of the Salisbury ministries).

title: Henry Northcote, 1st Baron Northcote
text: Henry Stafford Northcote, 1st Baron Northcote (18 November 1846 – 29 September 1911) was a British Conservative politician who served as the third Governor-General of Australia, in office from 1904 to 1908.

title: Henry Northcote, 1st Baron Northcote
text: He was previously Governor of Bombay from 1900 to 1903, as well as a government minister under Lord Salisbury.

title: Henry Northcote, 1st Baron Northcote
text: Northcote was the son of Stafford Northcote, 1st Earl of Iddesleigh.

title: Henry Northcote, 1st Baron Northcote
text: He was educated at Eton and Merton College, Oxford, and then worked for the Foreign Office and as private secretary to his father.

title: Henry Northcote, 1st Baron Northcote
text: Northcote was elected to the House of Commons in 1880, and served as Financial Secretary to the War Office (1885–86) and Surveyor-General of the Ordnance (1886–88) during Lord Salisbury's first and second terms as prime minister.

title: Henry Northcote, 1st Baron Northcote
text: Northcote was made Governor of Bombay in 1900, at which point he was raised to the peerage; he had previously been created a baronet in 1887.

title: Henry Northcote, 1st Baron Northcote
text: He became Governor-General of Australia in 1904, and brought much needed stability to the post – his two predecessors had both resigned after less than two years in office.

title: Henry Northcote, 1st Baron Northcote
text: Northcote played a relatively active role in politics, due to the unstable three-party system then in place.

title: Henry Northcote, 1st Baron Northcote
text: He served for almost five years, resigning in 1908 following a falling out with Prime Minister Alfred Deakin.

title: Karan Johar
text: Karan Kumar Johar (born Rahul Kumar Johar, 25 May 1972), often informally referred to as KJo, is an Indian film director, producer, screenwriter, costume designer, actor and television personality who works in Hindi films.

title: Karan Johar
text: He is the son of Hiroo Johar and the producer Yash Johar.

title: Karan Johar
text: Johar made his directorial debut with the widely-seen romance "Kuch Kuch Hota Hai" (1998), which earned him the Filmfare Awards for Best Director and Best Screenplay.

title: Karan Johar
text: His next two films were the ensemble dramas "Kabhi Khushi Kabhie Gham...

title: Karan Johar
text: " (2001) and "Kabhi Alvida Naa Kehna" (2006), which were both very successful in the overseas market.

title: Karan Johar
text: His social drama " My Name Is Khan" (2010) earned him his second Filmfare Award for Best Director.

title: Karan Johar
text: The 2018 spy thriller "Raazi" won him Filmfare Award for Best Film.

title: Karan Johar
text: These, along with the several successful films he has produced under the Dharma Productions banner, have established him as one of the leading director-producers in Hindi cinema.

title: Karan Johar
text: Johar has also ventured successfully into other avenues of the entertainment industry.

title: Karan Johar
text: He hosts a television talk show, "Koffee with Karan", and a radio show "Calling Karan", and appeared as a judge on competition reality shows "Jhalak Dikhhla JaaIndia's Got TalentIndia's Next Superstars".

title: Ae Dil Hai Mushkil
text: Ae Dil Hai Mushkil is an Indian 2016 Hindi-language musical romantic drama film directed, co-written and produced by Karan Johar.

title: Ae Dil Hai Mushkil
text: The story is based on the concept of unrequited love.

title: Ae Dil Hai Mushkil
text: The film stars Ranbir Kapoor, Anushka Sharma and Aishwarya Rai, with Fawad Khan appearing in a supporting role.

title: Ae Dil Hai Mushkil
text: It also features cameo appearances by Shah Rukh Khan and Alia Bhatt.

title: Ae Dil Hai Mushkil
text: The film was released on 28 October 2016 during the Diwali festival.

title: Ae Dil Hai Mushkil
text: Made with a budget of , "Ae Dil Hai Mushkil" was commercially successful, grossing over worldwide.

title: Ae Dil Hai Mushkil
text: It received mixed reviews, with criticism towards its direction, screenplay, dialogues and length, while Kapoor's performance and the soundtrack received praise.

title: Ae Dil Hai Mushkil
text: The film became one of the highest-grossing Hindi films of 2016 and Kapoor's first commercial success since his 2013 romantic comedy film "Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani".

title: Ae Dil Hai Mushkil
text: It received seven nominations at the 62nd Filmfare Awards, including Best Director (Johar), Best Actor (Kapoor) and Best Actress for Sharma, winning four of them for its soundtrack.

title: Ae Dil Hai Mushkil
text: The film is inspired by the lives of Kaushik Koppula and his friend with Ranbir Kapoor and Anushka Sharma reprising their roles while roles of Shah Rukh Khan and Aishwarya Rai were based on lives of his friend Kalyan and his love interest repestively.

title: Strelsa Brown
text: Brown's true name is Edna Brown Muss.

title: Strelsa Brown
text: She was married to Henry Muss, an infantry soldier, who was a World War II hero.

title: Strelsa Brown
text: Muss was killed in action in 1945.

title: Strelsa Brown
text: Early in her career she was a showgirl at the London Casino and modelled nude for the society photographer Horace Roye.

title: Strelsa Brown
text: In 1962, Brown claimed that she was owed between$ 2 and$ 3 million of a fortune begun by New York City builder Isaac Muss, the father of Henry Muss.

title: Strelsa Brown
text: No will was left.

title: Strelsa Brown
text: Until then she had lived purely on her war pension from the US.

title: Strelsa Brown
text: She had given up acting on stage as a soubrette, due to her age, to look after her son David.

title: Strelsa Brown
text: The brothers and sisters of her husband, Henry Muss, just prior to 1962 had given her an ultimatum ..

title: Strelsa Brown
text: sign that she agreed one of the wealthiest men in New York had left a total amount of$ 20.000 and they would continue to send$ 100 a month to her ...

title: Strelsa Brown
text: ( money they had started strangely to send just one year before at the time Isaac Muss had died) or else they would stop the monthly cheque.

title: Strelsa Brown

title: Clint Eastwood
text: Clinton Eastwood Jr.( born May 31, 1930) is an American actor, filmmaker, musician, and politician.

title: Clint Eastwood
text: After achieving success in the Western TV series" Rawhide", he rose to international fame with his role as the Man with No Name in Italian filmmaker Sergio Leone's" Dollars" Trilogy of spaghetti Westerns during the 1960s and as antihero cop Harry Callahan in the five" Dirty Harry" films throughout the 1970s and 1980s.

title: Clint Eastwood
text: These roles, among others, have made Eastwood an enduring cultural icon of masculinity.

title: Clint Eastwood
text: For his work in the Western film" Unforgiven"( 1992) and the sports drama" Million Dollar Baby"( 2004), Eastwood won Academy Awards for Best Director and Best Picture, as well as receiving nominations for Best Actor.

title: Clint Eastwood
text: Eastwood's greatest commercial successes have been the adventure comedy" Every Which Way But Loose"( 1978) and it s sequel, the action comedy" Any Which Way You Can"( 1980), after adjustment for inflation.

title: Clint Eastwood
text: Other popular films include the Western" Hang' Em High"( 1968), the psychological thriller" Play Misty for Me"( 1971), the crime film" Thunderbolt and Lightfoot"( 1974), the Western" The Outlaw Josey Wales"( 1976), the prison film" Escape from Alcatraz"( 1979), the action film" Firefox"( 1982), the suspense thriller" Tightrope"( 1984), the Western" Pale Rider"( 1985), the war films" Where Eagles Dare"( 1968)," Kelly's Heroes"( 1970), and" Heartbreak Ridge"( 1986), the action thriller" In the Line of Fire"( 1993), the romantic drama" The Bridges of Madison County"( 1995), and the drama" Gran Torino"( 2008).

title: Clint Eastwood
text: In addition to directing many of his own star vehicles, Eastwood has also directed films in which he did not appear, such as the mystery drama" Mystic River"( 2003) and the war film" Letters from Iwo Jima"( 2006), for which he received Academy Award nominations, the drama" Changeling"( 2008), and the South African biographical political sports drama" Invictus"( 2009).

title: Clint Eastwood
text: The war drama biopic" American Sniper"( 2014) set box- office records for the largest January release ever and was also the largest opening ever for an Eastwood film.

title: Giovanni Giorgi (composer)

title: Roman Hoffstetter
text: Roman Hoffstetter( born 24 April 1742, in Laudenbach, near Bad Mergentheim, Germany; died: 21 May( Baker's) or June(" New Grove" 2nd) 1815, in Miltenberg- am- Main, Germany; alternative spelling" Romanus Hoffstetter") was a classical composer and Benedictine monk who also admired Joseph Haydn almost to the point of imitation.

title: Roman Hoffstetter
text: Hoffstetter wrote" everything that flows from Haydn's pen seems to me so beautiful and remains so imprinted on my memory that I can not prevent myself now and again from imitating something as well as I can.

title: Roman Hoffstetter
text: " In 1965, the musicologist Alan Tyson( with H.C. Robbins Landon) published the finding that the entire set of six" String Quartets" long- admired as Haydn's Op.

title: Roman Hoffstetter
text: 3, including the" Andante cantabile" of No. 5 in F Major known as" Haydn's Serenade", were actually by Roman Hoffstetter.

title: Roman Hoffstetter
text: Further discoveries have more strongly established Hoffstetter's authorship of at least the first two of the six quartets.

title: Roman Hoffstetter
text: Little is known about his early training or life, though it is likely that he came from a musical family.

title: Roman Hoffstetter
text: He was a twin; the other was Johann Urban Alois Hoffstetter, who became director of the Franconian province of the Teutonic Order and also a small- time composer.

title: Roman Hoffstetter
text: Hoffstetter took his vows as Pater Romanus at the Benedictine monastery in Amorbach on 5 June 1763, and was ordained a priest on 10 September 1766.

title: Roman Hoffstetter
text: He succeeded in due time to the position of" Regens chori"( choir director), also functioning as an organist and on- call parish priest for smaller churches in the Odenwald region, although his principal position at the monastery was as culinary overseer( Küchenmeister).

title: Roman Hoffstetter
text: The majority of works written for Amorbach were lost in the dissolution of the monastery library by French forces in 1803.

title: Roman Hoffstetter
text: Following the secularization of Amorbach in 1803, Hoffstetter retired – almost completely deaf and blind – to Miltenberg- am- Main with his abbot, Benedikt Kuelsheimer.

title: Roman Hoffstetter
text: He died there 12 years later.

title: Roman Hoffstetter
text: Hoffstetter's music has the virtue of being memorable, with clear- cut themes that stay in the memory and make it easy to follow the musical development.

title: Roman Hoffstetter
text: Besides his string quartets( which have had to be carefully researched for stylistic earmarks that distinguish them clearly from Haydn), Hoffstetter composed at least ten Masses( several of which are preserved at the Archdiocesian Archives in Würzburg), as well as a number of smaller church works, including a lost" Miserere" on which he collaborated with Swedish- German composer Joseph Martin Kraus( 1756– 1792).

title: Roman Hoffstetter
text: The three viola concertos, one of which is actually a double concerto for viola and violoncello, were once offered for sale by the German firm of Breitkopf, but recent research has determined that these were actually composed by Kraus, not Hoffstetter, as the autograph of one of them in the Deutsche Staatsbibliothek clearly shows.

title: Roman Hoffstetter
text: Hoffstetter is best known for his friendship with Kraus, who was born in nearby Miltenberg- am- Main.

title: Roman Hoffstetter
text: Their friendship began as early as 1774 and continued through Kraus's appointment as court composer to Swedish King Gustav III, and on through to Kraus's death.

title: Roman Hoffstetter
text: Hoffstetter corresponded with both Kraus, and his early biographer, Swedish diplomat Fredrik Samuel Silverstolpe, who put him in touch with his idol, Haydn.

title: Roman Hoffstetter
text: Nine of these letters, written in 1800 to 1802, have been preserved in Silverstolpe's collection at Uppsala University library.

title: William Franklin
text: William Franklin FRSE (1730 – November 1813) was an American-born attorney, soldier, politician, and colonial administrator.

title: William Franklin
text: He was the acknowledged illegitimate son of Benjamin Franklin.

title: William Franklin
text: WIlliam Franklin was the last colonial Governor of New Jersey (1763–1776), and a steadfast Loyalist throughout the American Revolutionary War.

title: William Franklin
text: (In contrast, his father Benjamin was one of the most prominent of the Patriot leaders of the American Revolution and a Founding Father of the United States.

title: William Franklin
text: ) Following imprisonment by Patriots in 1776 to 1778, William became the chief leader of the Loyalists.

title: William Franklin
text: From his base in New York City, he organized military units to fight on the British side.

title: William Franklin
text: In 1782, he went into exile in Britain.

title: William Franklin
text: He lived in London until his death.

title: Ralph William Franklin
text: Ralph William Franklin( born January 3, 1947), commonly known as was R. William Franklin, was the eleventh Bishop of Western New York in the Episcopal Church between 2011 and 2019.

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: Benjamin Franklin (April 17, 1790) was an American polymath and one of the Founding Fathers of the United States.

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: Franklin was a leading writer, printer, political philosopher, politician, Freemason, postmaster, scientist, inventor, humorist, civic activist, statesman, and diplomat.

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: As a scientist, he was a major figure in the American Enlightenment and the history of physics for his discoveries and theories regarding electricity.

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: As an inventor, he is known for the lightning rod, bifocals, and the Franklin stove, among other inventions.

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: He founded many civic organizations, including the Library Company, Philadelphia's first fire department and the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: Franklin earned the title of "The First American" for his early and indefatigable campaigning for colonial unity, initially as an author and spokesman in London for several colonies.

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: As the first United States Ambassador to France, he exemplified the emerging American nation.

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: Franklin was foundational in defining the American ethos as a marriage of the practical values of thrift, hard work, education, community spirit, self-governing institutions, and opposition to authoritarianism both political and religious, with the scientific and tolerant values of the Enlightenment.

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: In the words of historian Henry Steele Commager, "In a Franklin could be merged the virtues of Puritanism without its defects, the illumination of the Enlightenment without its heat.

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: " To Walter Isaacson, this makes Franklin "the most accomplished American of his age and the most influential in inventing the type of society America would become.

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: " Franklin became a successful newspaper editor and printer in Philadelphia, the leading city in the colonies, publishing the "Pennsylvania Gazette" at the age of 23.

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: He became wealthy publishing this and "Poor Richard's Almanack", which he authored under the pseudonym "Richard Saunders".

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: After 1767, he was associated with the "Pennsylvania Chronicle", a newspaper that was known for its revolutionary sentiments and criticisms of British policies.

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: He pioneered and was the first president of Academy and College of Philadelphia which opened in 1751 and later became the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: He organized and was the first secretary of the American Philosophical Society and was elected president in 1769.

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: Franklin became a national hero in America as an agent for several colonies when he spearheaded an effort in London to have the Parliament of Great Britain repeal the unpopular Stamp Act.

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: An accomplished diplomat, he was widely admired among the French as American minister to Paris and was a major figure in the development of positive Franco-American relations.

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: His efforts proved vital for the American Revolution in securing shipments of crucial munitions from France.

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: He was promoted to deputy postmaster-general for the British colonies in 1753, having been Philadelphia postmaster for many years, and this enabled him to set up the first national communications network.

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: During the revolution, he became the first United States Postmaster General.

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: He was active in community affairs and colonial and state politics, as well as national and international affairs.

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: From 1785 to 1788, he served as governor of Pennsylvania.

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: He initially owned and dealt in slaves but, by the late 1750s, he began arguing against slavery and became an abolitionist.

title: Benjamin Franklin
text: His life and legacy of scientific and political achievement, and his status as one of America's most influential Founding Fathers, have seen Franklin honored more than two centuries after his death on coinage and the $100 bill, warships, and the names of many towns, counties, educational institutions, and corporations, as well as countless cultural references.

title: Etan Boritzer
text: Etan Boritzer( born 1950) is an American writer of children ’s literature who is best known for his book" What is God?

title: Etan Boritzer
text: " first published in 1989.

title: Etan Boritzer

title: Etan Boritzer

text: His essay was included in a special anthology by New York City public school children compiled and published by the New York City Department of Education.

text: Boritzer now lives in Venice, California and maintains his publishing office there also.

title: Ralph Dacre, 3rd Baron Dacre
text: Ralph Dacre, 3rd Baron Dacre( d.

title: Ralph Dacre, 3rd Baron Dacre
text: 1375) was an English noble and clergyman.

title: Ralph Dacre, 3rd Baron Dacre
text: He was the third son of Ralph Dacre, 1st Baron Dacre and his wife Margaret de Multon, 2nd Baroness Multon of Gilsland, with two older brothers( William and Thomas) and one younger brother( Hugh).

title: Ralph Dacre, 3rd Baron Dacre
text: He would become the second of three of the brothers to succeed to the title of Baron Dacre.

title: Ralph Dacre, 3rd Baron Dacre
text: As the third son, Ralph Dacre pursued a clerical career.

title: Ralph Dacre, 3rd Baron Dacre
text: He was placed as the rector of the church of Prescot in 1346( while still several months below canonical age), and was confirmed in this position in 1350 by Pope Clement VI.

title: Ralph Dacre, 3rd Baron Dacre
text: He is mentioned as" parson of Prescot" in visitation pedigrees, and he retained his position as rector until shortly before his death in 1375, when he resigned in favor of John Fairfax.

title: Ralph Dacre, 3rd Baron Dacre
text: Ralph Dacre succeeded to the title of Baron Dacre in 1361, on the death of his eldest brother William without issue( the next- oldest brother, Thomas, also being dead without issue before this time).

title: Ralph Dacre, 3rd Baron Dacre
text: He was summoned to Parliament in 1362.

title: Ralph Dacre, 3rd Baron Dacre
text: His time as baron was turbulent, with a particularly violent feud developing that would ultimately claim his life.

title: Ralph Dacre, 3rd Baron Dacre
text: In 1373, Nicholas Harrington led an armed party against Dacre's lands that caused extensive damage, including the destruction of buildings and the theft of cattle and other valuables; Harrington and the other offenders escaped consequences for the raid.

title: Ralph Dacre, 3rd Baron Dacre
text: In 1375, Baron Dacre was murdered, apparently by Harrington as well as his own brother, Hugh.

title: Ralph Dacre, 3rd Baron Dacre
text: Though both perpetrators were presented for the murder, they were never punished for it.

title: Ralph Dacre, 3rd Baron Dacre
text: Ralph Dacre died intestate, unmarried, and childless in 1375.

title: Ralph Dacre, 3rd Baron Dacre
text: His brother( and probable murderer) Hugh would succeed him as the fourth Baron Dacre.

title: Philippa de Neville
text: Philippa Neville, Baroness Dacre (1386–after 1453), was born at Raby Castle, Staindrop, Durham.

title: Philippa de Neville
text: Philippa Neville was the third daughter of Ralph Neville, 1st Earl of Westmorland, by his first wife, Margaret Stafford.

title: Philippa de Neville
text: She married, before 20 July 1399, Thomas Dacre, 6th Baron Dacre of Gilsland, born at Naworth Castle, Cumberland on 27 October 1387, the son of William Dacre, 5th Baron Dacre of Gilsland, by Joan Douglas, the illegitimate daughter of Sir William Douglas, 1st Earl of Douglas.

title: Philippa de Neville
text: They had seven sons and two daughters: Philippa's husband, Thomas Dacre, 6th Baron Dacre of Gilsland, died 5 January 1458.

title: Philippa de Neville
text: The date of Philippa's death is unknown, although she was living 8 July 1453.

title: Hugh Dacre, 4th Baron Dacre
text: Hugh Dacre, 4th Baron Dacre (1335–1383) was an English nobleman.

title: Hugh Dacre, 4th Baron Dacre
text: He was born in 1335, the youngest son of Ralph Dacre, 1st Baron Dacre and his wife Margaret de Multon, 2nd Baroness Multon of Gilsland.

title: Hugh Dacre, 4th Baron Dacre
text: His two older brothers preceded him in the barony, but both died childless.

title: Hugh Dacre, 4th Baron Dacre
text: His brother William, the second baron, married but died childless in 1361.

title: Hugh Dacre, 4th Baron Dacre
text: His brother Ralph, the third baron, was a clergyman who died unmarried and without issue in 1375.

title: Hugh Dacre, 4th Baron Dacre
text: Hugh may have been implicated in his predecessor's death; he and Nicholas Harrington were excommunicated by the Archbishop of York, likely in connection with the murder, and they were both presented for the murder at Preston, though they escaped long-term repercussions.

title: Hugh Dacre, 4th Baron Dacre
text: Dacre, like many noblemen of his time, pursued a military career.

title: Hugh Dacre, 4th Baron Dacre
text: He fought in the Hundred Years War in France and Flanders.

title: Hugh Dacre, 4th Baron Dacre
text: Upon his return to England, he was one of the commissioners of the Western Marches.

title: Hugh Dacre, 4th Baron Dacre
text: Dacre married Ela (or Elizabeth) Maxwell, said to be the daughter of Alexander Maxwell, of the family that owned Caerlaverock Castle in Scotland.

title: Hugh Dacre, 4th Baron Dacre
text: Their son, William succeeded to the barony upon Hugh's death in 1383.

title: Thomas Dacre (knight)
text: Sir Thomas Dacre( 1410 – 15 January 1448) was born in Brampton, Cumberland, England.

title: Thomas Dacre (knight)
text: Dacre's father was Thomas Dacre, 6th Baron Dacre and his mother was Philippa de Neville.

title: Thomas Dacre (knight)
text: He married Elizabeth Bowett, daughter of Sir William Bowett of Horsford and Amy de Ufford.

title: Thomas Dacre (knight)
text: Elizabeth was born 1405 in Horsfordburgh, St. Margaret's, Norfolk, England.

title: Thomas Dacre (knight)
text: Children of Sir Thomas Dacre:

title: Magdalen Dacre
text: Magdalen Dacre, Viscountess Montagu( January 1538 – 8 April 1608) was an English noblewoman.

title: Magdalen Dacre
text: She was the daughter of William Dacre, 3rd Baron Dacre of Gilsland, and the second wife of Anthony Browne, 1st Viscount Montagu.

title: Magdalen Dacre
text: Magdalen, a fervent Roman Catholic, was a Maid of Honour at the wedding of Mary I of England to Philip II of Spain in Winchester Cathedral.

title: Magdalen Dacre
text: Dacre, despite being a Catholic, managed to remain in high regard with the Protestant Tudor Queen who succeeded Mary, Elizabeth I. Dacre was, according to biographer Lady Antonia Fraser in her historical biography," The Gunpowder Plot: Terror and Faith in 1605", a fine example of" how the most pious Catholic could survive if he( or she) did not challenge the accepted order".

title: Ralph Dacre, 1st Baron Dacre
text: Ralph (or Ranulph) Dacre, 1st Baron Dacre (ca.

title: Ralph Dacre, 1st Baron Dacre
text: 1290 – April 1339) was an English peer.

title: Ralph Dacre, 1st Baron Dacre
text: Dacre was the son of Sir William Dacre of Cumberland.

title: Ralph Dacre, 1st Baron Dacre
text: In 1321 he was summoned to the House of Lords as Lord Dacre.

title: Ralph Dacre, 1st Baron Dacre
text: In 1331 he was appointed High Sheriff of Cumberland and Governor of Carlisle.

title: Ralph Dacre, 1st Baron Dacre
text: He married Margaret de Multon, Baroness Multon of Gilsland.

title: Ralph Dacre, 1st Baron Dacre
text: Dacre carried of his bride to be, a ward of Edward III, from Warwick Castle where she was in the care of Thomas de Beauchamp; the official record states: Ranulph de Dacre pardoned for stealing away in the night, out of the King's custodie, from his Castell of Warwick, of Margaret, daughter and heir of Thomas Multon of Gillsland, who held of the King "in capite" and was within age, whereof the said Ranulph standeth indighted "in curia Regis".

title: Ralph Dacre, 1st Baron Dacre
text: He commanded the English in the Battle of Dornock.

title: Ralph Dacre, 1st Baron Dacre
text: Lord Dacre died in April 1339 and was succeeded in the barony by his eldest son, William.

title: Princess Mathilde of Saxony (born 1936)
text: Princess Mathilde of Saxony, Duchess of Saxony (17 January 1936 – 18 March 2018) was a Princess of Saxony and member of the House of Wettin by birth and a Princess of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha as consort to Prince Johannes Heinrich of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha.

title: Princess Mathilde of Saxony (born 1936)
text: Mathilde is the fifth and youngest child of Friedrich Christian, Margrave of Meissen and his wife, Princess Elisabeth Helene of Thurn and Taxis, and a younger sister of Maria Emanuel, Margrave of Meissen, the late head of the Royal House of Saxony and senior claimant to the defunct throne of the Kingdom of Saxony.

title: Princess Teresa Cristina of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha

text: Hubertus Michael, Hereditary Prince of Saxe- Coburg and Gotha, Duke of Saxony( born 16 September 1975) is the heir- apparent of the head of the family which ruled the Duchy of Saxe- Coburg and Gotha until 1918.

title: Kelly Rondestvedt
text: Kelly, Hereditary Princess of Saxe- Coburg and Gotha, Duchess of Saxony( born Kelly Jeanne Rondestvedt on 10 January 1975) is an American investment banker.

title: Kelly Rondestvedt

title: Prince August Leopold of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha
text: Prince August Leopold of Saxe- Coburg and Gotha( December 6, 1867 – October 11, 1922), known in Brazil as Dom Augusto Leopoldo, was a prince of the Empire of Brazil and of the House of Saxe- Coburg and Gotha- Koháry.

title: Prince August Leopold of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha
text: He was the second of four sons born to German Prince Ludwig August of Saxe- Coburg and Gotha and Princess Leopoldina of Brazil.

title: Prince August Leopold of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha
text: The second grandson of the Emperor Pedro II, the prince was, for some years between the presumptive heirs to the Imperial Crown of Brazil.

title: Prince August Leopold of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha
text: Their descendants would form the Saxe- Coburg and Gotha branch of the Imperial House of Brazil.

title: Prince Johannes of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha
text: ", in German: "Johannes Albert Leopold Friedrich Christian Erbprinz von Sachsen-Coburg-Kohary" (17 November 1969, in Innsbruck – 21 August 1987, in Ortler) was a German royal (prince from the House of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha-Koháry) and presumed heir of his maternal uncle, the childless Maria Emanuel, Margrave of Meissen, Head of the Royal House of Saxony.

title: Prince Johannes of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha
text: Johannes was the only child of the Princess Mathilde of Saxony, the youngest daughter of Frederick Christian, Margrave of Meissen, thus a granddaughter of Frederick August III of Saxony who was deposed in 1918.

title: Prince Johannes of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha
text: Mathilde's brothers did not have any children, and her elder sister Anna's issue with Roberto de Afif were deemed lower-born than the uncontested dynastic Prince Johannes.

title: Prince Johannes of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha
text: Because his maternal uncles were already middle-aged and childless, Johannes was groomed from his youth to become the heir of the Royal House of Saxony. However, Johannes died at seventeen on 21 August 1987 in a climbing accident.

title: Prince Johannes of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha
text: He had gone on a climbing expedition on his own, telling his parents that he was headed to one site, but actually heading to a different, and riskier mountain.

title: Prince Johannes of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha
text: When Johannes did not return home when expected, his worried parents notified the authorities.

title: Prince Johannes of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha
text: Search parties were organized and helicopters were used to scour the region. His lifeless body was spotted from a helicopter, thus bringing the search to a tragic end.

title: Prince Johannes of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha
text: The loss of Johannes was a devastating blow to his desolated parents. However, due to the tragedy, it also left his mother's family without a clear dynastic and eligible heir, and also left his father without a direct male heir.

title: Prince Johannes of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha
text: Prince Johannes Heinrich of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha had fathered a daughter, Felicitas, from his previous marriage to Baroness Gabriele von Fürstenberg.

title: Andreas, Prince of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha
text: Andreas, Prince of Saxe- Coburg and Gotha, Duke of Saxony( given names:" Andreas Michael Friedrich Hans Armin Siegfried Hubertus"; born 21 March 1943) has been the head of the House of Saxe- Coburg and Gotha since 1998.

title: Andreas, Prince of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha
text: He is the grandson of Charles Edward, the last ruling duke of Saxe- Coburg and Gotha.

title: Princess Dorothea of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha
text: Princess Dorothea Maria Henriette Auguste Louise of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha (30 April 1881 – 21 January 1967) was a princess of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha by birth and the duchess of Schleswig-Holstein through her marriage to Ernst Gunther, duke of Schleswig-Holstein.

title: Princess Dorothea of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha
text: Dorothea was born in Vienna, Austria, the second child and only daughter of Prince Philipp of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha and Princess Louise of Belgium.

title: Prince Johannes Heinrich of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha
text: Prince Johannes Heinrich of Saxe- Coburg and Gotha( Johannes Heinrich Friedrich Werner Konrad Rainer Maria; Slovak:" Ján Henrich", Hungarian:" János Henrik"; 28 March 1931, in Innsbruck – 14 April 2010, in Innsbruck) was a prince of the House of Saxe- Coburg and Gotha- Koháry and the last holder of Csábrág and Szitnya, both in modern -day Slovakia, lost to the communist regime of Czechoslovakia.

title: Prince Johannes Heinrich of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha
text: He was the only son of Prince Rainer of Saxe- Coburg and Gotha by his first wife, Johanna Károlyi de Károly- Patty.

title: Beaulieu-sur-Loire
text: Beaulieu- sur- Loire is a commune in the Loiret department in north -central France.

title: Beaulieu-sur-Loire

title: John Jay
text: John Jay (December 23, 1745 – May 17, 1829) was an American statesman, patriot, diplomat, Founding Father of the United States, abolitionist, negotiator and signatory of the Treaty of Paris of 1783, second Governor of New York, and the first Chief Justice of the United States (1789–1795).

title: John Jay
text: He directed U.S. foreign policy for much of the 1780s and was an important leader of the Federalist Party after the ratification of the United States Constitution in 1788.

title: John Jay
text: Jay was born into a wealthy family of merchants and New York City government officials of French and Dutch descent.

title: John Jay
text: He became a lawyer and joined the New York Committee of Correspondence, organizing opposition to British policies in the time preceding the American Revolution.

title: John Jay
text: Jay was elected to the Second Continental Congress, and served as President of the Congress.

title: John Jay
text: From 1779 to 1782, Jay served as the ambassador to Spain; he persuaded Spain to provide financial aid to the fledgling United States.

title: John Jay
text: He also served as a negotiator of the Treaty of Paris, in which Britain recognized American independence.

title: John Jay
text: Following the end of the war, Jay served as Secretary of Foreign Affairs, directing United States foreign policy under the Articles of Confederation government.

title: John Jay
text: He also served as the first Secretary of State on an interim basis.

title: John Jay
text: A proponent of strong, centralized government, Jay worked to ratify the United States Constitution in New York in 1788.

title: John Jay
text: He was a co-author of "The Federalist Papers" along with Alexander Hamilton and James Madison, and wrote five of the 85 essays.

title: John Jay
text: After the establishment of the new federal government, Jay was appointed by President George Washington the first Chief Justice of the United States, serving from 1789 to 1795.

title: John Jay
text: The Jay Court experienced a light workload, deciding just four cases over six years.

title: John Jay
text: In 1794, while serving as Chief Justice, Jay negotiated the highly controversial Jay Treaty with Britain.

title: John Jay
text: Jay received a handful of electoral votes in three of the first four presidential elections, but never undertook a serious bid for the presidency.

title: John Jay
text: Jay served as the Governor of New York from 1795 to 1801.

title: John Jay
text: Long an opponent of slavery, he helped enact a law that provided for the gradual emancipation of slaves, and the institution of slavery was abolished in New York in Jay's lifetime.

title: John Jay
text: In the waning days of President John Adams's administration, Jay was confirmed by the Senate for another term as Chief Justice, but he declined the position and retired to his farm in Westchester County, New York, where he died.

title: List of presidents of Sarah Lawrence College
text: These are the presidents of Sarah Lawrence College in Westchester, New York.

title: Motherland (disambiguation)
text: Motherland is the place of one's birth, the place of one's ancestors, or the place of origin of an ethnic group.

title: Motherland (disambiguation)
text: Motherland may also refer to:

title: Place of birth
text: The place of birth( POB) or birthplace is the place where a person was born.

title: Place of birth
text: This place is often used in legal documents, together with name and date of birth, to uniquely identify a person.

title: Place of birth
text: As a general rule with respect to passports, the place of birth is determined to be the country that currently has" sovereignty" over the actual place of birth, regardless of when the birth actually occurred.

title: Place of birth
text: The place of birth is not necessarily the place where the parents of the new baby live.

title: Place of birth
text: If the baby is born in a hospital in another place, that place is the place of birth.

title: Place of birth
text: In many countries, this also means that the government requires that the birth of the new baby is registered in the place of birth.

title: Place of birth
text: Some countries place less or no importance on the place of birth, instead using alternative geographical characteristics for the purpose of identity documents.

title: Place of birth
text: For example, Sweden has used the concept of" födelsehemortdomicile of birth") since 1947.

title: Place of birth
text: This means that the domicile of the baby's mother is the registered place of birth.

title: Place of birth
text: The location of the maternity ward or other physical birthplace is considered unimportant.

title: Place of birth
text: Similarly, Switzerland uses the concept of" Heimatortlieu d'origineluogo d'origineplace of origin" in German, French and Italian respectively).

title: Place of birth
text: A child born to Swiss parents is automatically assigned the place of origin of the parent with the same last name, so the child either gets their mother's or father's place of origin.

title: Place of birth
text: A child born to one Swiss parent and one foreign parent acquires the place of origin of their Swiss parent.

title: Place of birth
text: In a Swiss passport and identity card, the holder's place of origin is stated, not their place of birth.

title: Place of birth
text: In some countries( primarily in the Americas), the place of birth automatically determines the nationality of the baby, a practice often referred to by the Latin phrase" jus soli".

title: Place of birth
text: Almost all countries outside the Americas instead attribute nationality based on the nationality( ies) of the baby's parents( referred to as" jus sanguinis").

title: Place of birth
text: There can be some confusion regarding the place of birth if the birth takes place in an unusual way: when babies are born on an airplane or at sea, difficulties can arise.

title: Place of birth
text: The place of birth of such a person depends on the law of the countries involved, which include the nationality of the plane or ship, the nationality( ies) of the parents and/ or the location of the plane or ship( if the birth occurs in the territorial waters or airspace of a country).

title: Place of birth
text: Some administrative forms may request the applicant's" country of birth".

title: Place of birth
text: It is important to determine from the requester whether the information requested refers to the applicant's" place of birth" or" nationality at birth".

title: Place of birth
text: For US citizens born abroad who under the US Constitution acquire US citizenship at the time of birth, the nationality at birth will be USA( American), while the place of birth would be the country in which the actual birth takes place.

title: Sennedjem
text: The Ancient Egyptian artisan Sennedjem lived in Set Maat( translated as" The Place of Truth"), contemporary Deir el- Medina, on the west bank of the Nile, opposite Thebes, during the reigns of Seti I and Ramesses II.

title: Sennedjem
text: Sennedjem had the title" Servant in the Place of Truth".

title: Sennedjem
text: He was buried along with his wife, Iyneferti, and family in a tomb in the village necropolis.

title: Sennedjem
text: His tomb was discovered January 31, 1886.

title: Sennedjem
text: When Sennedjem's tomb was found, in it there was regular furniture from his home, including a stool and a bed, which he actually used when he was alive.

title: Sennedjem
text: His titles included Servant in the Place of Truth, meaning that he worked on the excavation and decoration of the nearby royal tombs.
